'''Barrelhouse Chuck''' (born '''Charles Goering''', July 10, 1958) is an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] pianist, keyboardist, singer, and songwriter.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p64492|pure_url=yes}}|title=Barrelhouse Chuck |author= |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=December 11, 2011}}</ref>

He claims to be the only Chicago blues pianist to have studied under [[Sunnyland Slim]], [[Pinetop Perkins]], [[Blind John Davis]], [[Detroit Junior]] and [[Little Brother Montgomery]].<ref name="Barrelhouse"/>  To date, his work has appeared on fourteen [[album]]s.<ref name="Albums">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=barrelhouse-chuck-p64492/discography/main|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( Barrelhouse Chuck > Discography > Main Albums )))}}</ref>

==Life and career==
He was born and raised in [[Columbus, Ohio]], [[United States]], and learned to play the [[drum kit|drums]] by the age of six.<ref name="Hanson"/>  He later graduated to the piano, and had relocated with his family to [[Gainesville, Florida]], before he first heard a [[Muddy Waters]] [[gramophone record|record]].<ref name="Barrelhouse"/> It was by listening to blues records that Barrelhouse Chuck learned the techniques of blues piano playing.<ref name="Hanson">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press
| location= [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States
| pages= 122–3
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref>  He formed his own bands including The Red Rooster Band and Red House plus Barrelhouse Chuck & The Blue Lights  in his teenage years, and followed Muddy Waters around the [[Southern United States]] trying to pick up playing tips from his pianist Pinetop Perkins. In 1979, he drove from Florida to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], to introduce himself to Sunnyland Slim.  Barrelhouse Chuck spent the next decade and a half studying his playing, along with other Chicago blues musicians including Blind John Davis, Little Brother Montgomery and [[Erwin Helfer]]. In the company of Montgomery for a long time, Barrelhouse Chuck later remarked "Little Brother was like a grandfather to me".<ref name="Barrelhouse">{{cite web |url=http://www.barrelhousechuck.com/bio.html |title=Barrelhouse Chuck Biography |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Barrelhousechuck.com |accessdate=December 11, 2011}}</ref>

Over the years, Barrelhouse Chuck has played or recorded with [[Jimmy Rogers]], [[Eddie Taylor]], [[Hubert Sumlin]], [[Otis Rush]], [[Buddy Guy]], and [[Otis "Big Smokey" Smothers]].<ref name="Barrelhouse"/> For a time in the late 1990s he played with [[Mississippi Heat]], and undertook a tour with [[Nick Moss| Nick Moss and the Flip Tops]].<ref name="Hanson"/>

His debut [[album]], ''Salute to Sunnyland Slim'', was released on Blue Loon Records in 1999, and contained supporting work from [[S.P. Leary]], [[Calvin "Fuzz" Jones]] and [[Willie "Big Eyes" Smith]].<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=salute-to-sunnyland-slim-r388396|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( ''Salute to Sunnyland Slim'' > Barrelhouse Chuck > Overview )))}}</ref> It was re-issued in 2005. The follow-up was ''Prescription for the Blues'' (2002), when Erwin Helfer appeared on three tracks.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=prescription-for-the-blues-r599680/review|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( ''Prescription for the Blues'' > Barrelhouse Chuck > Review )))}}</ref><ref name="Albums"/> [[Kim Wilson]] played the [[harmonica]] on Barrelhouse Chuck's 2006 offering, ''Got My Eyes on You''.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=album/got-my-eyes-on-you-r930752/credits|pure_url=yes}}|title=Allmusic ((( ''Got My Eyes on You'' > Barrelhouse Chuck > Credits )))}}</ref>

In February 2008, Wilson asked Barrelhouse Chuck to assist in recording the [[Cadillac Records: Music from the Motion Picture|soundtrack]] for the [[film]], ''[[Cadillac Records]]''.<ref name="Barrelhouse"/> His other credits include numerous appearances at the [[Chicago Blues Festival]].<ref name="Barrelhouse"/>

As of 2012, Barrelhouse Chuck maintains a full performance schedule in Chicago, around the United States, and occasionally abroad, including a regular solo appearance on Wednesday nights at The Barrelhouse Flat, a bar in [[Lincoln Park, Chicago|Lincoln Park]].<ref name="Schedule">{{cite web|url=http://www.barrelhousechuck.com/calendar.html |title=Calendar for Barrelhouse Chuck - Chicago Blues Piano |publisher=Barrelhousechuck.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}}</ref>

On February 24, 2012, Barrelhouse Chuck played at the "Howlin' For Hubert" concert at The Apollo Theater.

In 2013 and 2014, Barrelhouse Chuck was nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in the 'Pinetop Perkins Piano Player' category. In 2014 ''Drifting from Town to Town'' was nominated for a Blues Music Award in the 'Traditional Blues Album Award Of The Year' category.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blues.org/#ref=bluesmusicawards_nominees|title=Blues Music Awards Nominees - 2013 - 34th Blues Music Awards|publisher=Blues.org|accessdate=2013-03-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}}</ref>
